DOC.HEAD: East European Key Dates
With Romania Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some key dates for change in Eastern Europe this year: AUG. 18-19 _ Poland's leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, announces the first non-Communist government in POLAND since World War II, nominating Solidarity activist Tadeusz Mazowiecki as prime minister after Solidarity swept June elections. OCT. 7 _ The Communist Party in HUNGARY formally disbands, reconstituting itself as Hungarian Socialist Party. Parliament rewrites the constitution and adopts laws allowing several parties to contest free elections next year. NOV. 9 _ EAST GERMANY lifts travel restrictions and opens gateways through Berlin Wall three weeks after resignation of Communist Party chief Erich Honecker, who supervised the building of the wall in 1961. Honecker's hand-picked replacement Egon Krenz and the ruling party Politburo resigns a month later after Parliament voted to eliminate the party's constitutionally guaranteed hold on power. NOV. 10 _ Communist Party chief Todor Zhivkov of BULGARIA is ousted and replaced by a moderate. NOV. 29 _ In CZECHOSLOVAKIA, Parliament deletes the leading role of the Communist Party from the constitution after massive protests force the resignations of hard-line party chief Milos Jakes and the Politburo. DEC. 22 _ President Nicolae Ceausescu of ROMANIA, the last hard-line ruler in the Soviet bloc, is overthrown by a week-long popular revolt during which hundreds of demonstrators were killed by security forces.
